title: An extensive allelic series of Drosophila kae1 mutants reveals diverse and tissue-specific requirements for t6A biogenesis
background: N6-threonylcarbamoyl-adenosine (t6A) is a universal tRNA modification that stabilizes codon-anticodon interactions and is essential for translational fidelity. While extensively studied in single-celled organisms, its role in metazoan development and tissue-specific requirements remain poorly understood.
objective: To characterize the biological consequences of t6A loss in a metazoan system using an extensive allelic series of Drosophila kae1 mutants, the core enzyme in t6A biosynthesis.
methods: EMS mutagenesis screen, genetic complementation tests, biochemical analysis of tRNA modifications (primer extension assays, LC-MS/MS), yeast complementation assays, immunohistochemistry, clonal analysis in imaginal discs, and tissue-specific RNAi knockdown.
results: kae1 mutants showed tissue-specific requirements with complete loss of imaginal discs (highly mitotic tissues) while maintaining non-proliferating tissues for weeks. Mutants exhibited hematopoietic overgrowth, lamellocyte differentiation, melanotic tumors, and extended larval periods (up to 18 days vs normal 5 days). t6A levels decreased but were not eliminated even in null mutants.
conclusion: t6A modification exhibits tissue-specific requirements in metazoans, being essential for proliferating tissues but dispensable for many non-proliferating tissues, revealing fundamental differences in translational requirements between cell types.

learning_notes.note: The t6A modification is universally conserved and essential for translational fidelity, with kae1 serving as the core enzyme in its biosynthesis pathway. Drosophila kae1 mutants showed substantial but not complete loss of t6A-modified tRNAs (40% decrease in null mutants), suggesting either exceptional tRNA stability or mitochondrial contribution.

kae1 mutants exhibited striking tissue-specific requirements: completely lacking imaginal discs (highly proliferative tissues) while maintaining non-proliferating tissues like musculature and nervous system for extended periods (up to 18 days vs normal 5-day larval period).

Hematopoietic defects included lymph gland overgrowth, ectopic lamellocyte differentiation, and melanotic tumor formation, with mutant larvae showing increased mitotic cells in hematopoietic tissues and circulating lymph gland fragments in hemolymph.

Clonal analysis demonstrated that kae1 mutant cells were rapidly eliminated from proliferating imaginal disc tissues, indicating cell-autonomous requirements for t6A in mitotic cells despite potential maternal contribution of t6A-modified tRNAs.

Drosophila Kae1 and other t6A pathway components functionally complemented corresponding yeast null mutants, with combinations of fly kae1 + bud32 providing the best rescue of both growth defects and t6A modification levels in yeast.

Tissue-specific RNAi revealed differential requirements within the same tissue: eye-specific kae1 knockdown during proliferation (ey-Gal4) caused severe developmental defects, while knockdown in post-mitotic photoreceptors (GMR-Gal4) had no effect.

The extensive allelic series (including null, strong, and weak hypomorphs) revealed allele-specific phenotypic severities in different tissues, with some tissues showing sensitivity even to mild t6A reduction while others tolerated severe reduction.
